elements.content: Lead (Pb) is one of the most widespread toxic heavy metals, and how to quickly and completely remove trace Pb­(II) is a global concern. Herein, we prepared a novel metal–organic framework (MOF) {[Cd­(ADB)­L2]·1.5DMF·2H2O} n (1) decorated with carbomethoxy groups and investigated the Pb­(II) removal performance as well as the underlying mechanism. The MOF exhibits a fast kinetics with the kinetic rate constant k 2 of 0.162 g mg–1 min–1, which is 1–3 orders of magnitude higher than the reported Pb­(II) adsorbent materials. In addition, even in a concentration of 0.1 ppm, a high removal efficiency (96%) was still obtained after the treatment with the metal–organic framework, and the concentration was reduced to 0.004 ppm, which is well below the drinking water standard of the World Health Organization (0.01 ppm). The possible adsorption mechanism was systematically verified by Fourier-transform infrared and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy investigations. The significant affinity between carbomethoxy groups and Pb­(II) is responsible for the good removal performance.

elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Heavy metal pollution is becoming a global environmental concern because of its high toxicity and adverse effects on humanity and other organisms. Unlike many organic pollutants, these inorganic heavy metal ions are not susceptible to biological degradation and can be accumulated in the ecosystem and human body. So, heavy metal ions are highly toxic, even at low concentration. Pb(II) is regarded as one of the most toxic heavy metal ions, which can be chronically accumulated in human body, causing severe damages to the reproductive system, nervous system, kidney, liver, and brain. As a consequence, the development of efficient techniques to capture Pb(II) from wastewater is of urgent need.

elements.content: To date, extensive methods have been developed and improved to eliminate Pb­(II), such as membrane filtration, ion exchange, flocculation, biological treatment, chemical precipitation, and adsorption. Most of them are effective at high initial concentrations, and the removal performance are not satisfactory due to their higher residual concentration and longer detention time. Among these removal techniques, adsorption stands out considering its efficiency and economic competitiveness. Therefore, developing more efficient adsorbents, especially aiming at low concentration, is of paramount importance to water safety.
elements.clean_text: To date, extensive methods have been developed and improved to eliminate Pb(II), such as membrane filtration, ion exchange, flocculation, biological treatment, chemical precipitation, and adsorption. Most of them are effective at high initial concentrations, and the removal performance are not satisfactory due to their higher residual concentration and longer detention time. Among these removal techniques, adsorption stands out considering its efficiency and economic competitiveness. Therefore, developing more efficient adsorbents, especially aiming at low concentration, is of paramount importance to water safety.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted widespread attention in view of their ordered crystalline structure, extraordinary internal surface area, controllable porosity, and predesigned functional groups. Owing to these intriguing features, they have been considered to be the leading candidate for capture of heavy metal ions. Through ligand modification or MOF postfunctionalization, diverse functional groups can be rationally introduced into MOFs, resulting in special chemical and physical properties for heavy metal ion removal. A Zn-based MOF prepared from carboxyl/hydroxyl and pyridyl/acylamide ligands could effectively capture UO2(I) and Hg­(II). Xu et al. demonstrated the construction of Zn/Zr-based MOFs by combinations of carboxyl/thiol or carboxyl/thiol-ether, which displayed favorable adsorption performance for Hg­(II). An azine-decorated Zn­(II) MOF was explored as sorbent to capture heavy metal ions of Cu­(II), Cr­(III), Co­(II), Cd­(II), and Pb­(II). In these MOFs, functional groups of acylamide, hydroxyl, azine thiol, and thiol-ether did not involve the processes of self-assembly, but worked as the hand to capture heavy metal ions. As for Pb­(II) removal, a large number of reported MOFs showed good performances, but efficient removal from a low concentration system remains a great challenge.
elements.clean_text: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted widespread attention in view of their ordered crystalline structure, extraordinary internal surface area, controllable porosity, and predesigned functional groups. Owing to these intriguing features, they have been considered to be the leading candidate for capture of heavy metal ions. Through ligand modification or MOF postfunctionalization, diverse functional groups can be rationally introduced into MOFs, resulting in special chemical and physical properties for heavy metal ion removal. A Zn-based MOF prepared from carboxyl/hydroxyl and pyridyl/acylamide ligands could effectively capture UO2(I) and Hg(II). Xu et al. demonstrated the construction of Zn/Zr-based MOFs by combinations of carboxyl/thiol or carboxyl/thiol-ether, which displayed favorable adsorption performance for Hg(II). An azine-decorated Zn(II) MOF was explored as sorbent to capture heavy metal ions of Cu(II), Cr(III), Co(II), Cd(II), and Pb(II). In these MOFs, functional groups of acylamide, hydroxyl, azine thiol, and thiol-ether did not involve the processes of self-assembly, but worked as the hand to capture heavy metal ions. As for Pb(II) removal, a large number of reported MOFs showed good performances, but efficient removal from a low concentration system remains a great challenge.

elements.content: Herein, a carbomethoxy-functionalized MOF was constructed for the removal of Pb­(II) from aqueous solution. In this design, the 2,2′-azodibenzoic acid (denoted as H2ADB) and (pyridin-3-yl)­methyl 4-(2-(4-((pyridin-3-yl)­methoxy)­phenyl)­diazenyl)­benzoate] (denoted as L, ) were elaborately selected as ligands to assemble MOFs based on these considerations: (a) the carboxyl of H2ADB and pyridyl N atom of L are predisposed as the primary groups to participate in MOF construction, while the weaker and generally neutral binding groups of carbomethoxy, methoxy, and diazene are left as free-standing to capture heavy metal ions. In previous studies, various ester-functionalized materials were explored to capture heavy metal ions, and the ester groups played a vital role in the sorption process. (b) The abundant electron-donating O atoms of carbomethoxy groups in the pores of MOF would endow Pb­(II) with fast sorption kinetics by reducing pore diffusion. (c) The significant affinity of sufficient adsorption sites in the pores would afford a high removal efficiency for Pb­(II), even in a low concentration. In this study, the reaction of H2ADB and L with Cd­(OAc)2·2H2O produced a carbomethoxy/methoxy/diazene-decorated MOF, {[Cd­(ADB)­L2]·1.5DMF·2H2O} n (1) (DMF = N,N-dimethylformamide), which could efficiently remove Pb­(II) from a low concentration system without sample pretreatment. Specifically, adsorption experiments and related characterizations were conducted to investigate the sorption performance as well as the underlying adsorption mechanism.

In previous studies, various ester-functionalized materials were explored to capture heavy metal ions, and the ester groups played a vital role in the sorption process. (b) The abundant electron-donating O atoms of carbomethoxy groups in the pores of MOF would endow Pb(II) with fast sorption kinetics by reducing pore diffusion. (c) The significant affinity of sufficient adsorption sites in the pores would afford a high removal efficiency for Pb(II), even in a low concentration. In this study, the reaction of H2ADB and L with Cd(OAc)2⋅2H2O produced a carbomethoxy/methoxy/diazene-decorated MOF, {[Cd(ADB)L2]⋅1.5DMF⋅2H2O} n  (1) (DMF = N,N-dimethylformamide), which could efficiently remove Pb(II) from a low concentration system without sample pretreatment. Specifically, adsorption experiments and related characterizations were conducted to investigate the sorption performance as well as the underlying adsorption mechanism.

Experimental Section

Preparation of {[Cd(ADB)L2]⋅1.5DMF⋅2H2O} n  (1)

Cd(OAc)2⋅2H2O (11 mg, 0.04 mmol), H2ADB (5 mg, 0.02 mmol), L ligand (9 mg, 0.02 mmol), and 4 mL of DMF/H2O (1:1 V/V) were added into a 10 mL vial and sealed. The mixture was heated at 363 K for 72 h, then cooled to ambient temperature (5 °C h-1). Orange blocks of 1 were collected, washed with H2O, and dried in air. Yield: 5 mg (41%, based on L). Anal. Calcd for C68.5H62.5N11.5CdO13.5: C, 59.83; H, 4.58; N, 11.71. Found: C, 59.49; H, 4.12; N, 11.45. elements.content: All adsorption tests were conducted at 298 K using 7 mg of MOF 1 and 100 mL of Pb­(II) standard solution, except that the adsorption thermodynamics were performed at 298–318 K. The adsorbents with particle size ranging between 2.5 and 5.5 μm were well grinded before adsorption measurement (Figure S2). To evaluate the influence of pH on Pb­(II) uptake capacity, adsorbents were added into Pb­(II) solution of 3 ppm at different pH under continuous stirring. The varied pH values were adjusted by HNO3 or NaOH solutions with the concentration of 0.1 mol L–1.
elements.clean_text:
Adsorption Experiment

All adsorption tests were conducted at 298 K using 7 mg of MOF 1 and 100 mL of Pb(II) standard solution, except that the adsorption thermodynamics were performed at 298-318 K. The adsorbents with particle size ranging between 2.5 and 5.5 μm were well grinded before adsorption measurement (Figure S2). To evaluate the influence of pH on Pb(II) uptake capacity, adsorbents were added into Pb(II) solution of 3 ppm at different pH under continuous stirring. The varied pH values were adjusted by HNO3 or NaOH solutions with the concentration of 0.1 mol L-1.

elements.content: For kinetic studies, 7 mg of adsorbents were added into Pb­(II) solution (3 ppm) under continuous stirring at the optimum pH of 7.0. After taken from the mixed solution at given time intervals, analytical samples were immediately separated by centrifugation. The residual concentration of Pb­(II) was measured by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES) or atomic absorption spectroscopy (AAS) (for extra low ion concentration).

The amount of Pb­(II) adsorbed on the adsorbent q t (mg g–1) and removal efficiency were calculated according to the following formula: q t = ( C 0 − C t ) V m removal efficiency ( % ) = C 0 − C e C 0 × 100 where C 0 (mg L–1) and C e (mg L–1) are the initial and equilibrium concentration of Pb­(II), respectively. V (L) is the volume of the solution, and m (g) is the mass of the adsorbent. All the experiments were performed in triplicate and consistent results were reported.

elements.content: To assess the recyclability of MOF 1, the desorption measurements were tested. The Pb­(II)-loaded samples were immersed in 0.1 mmol L–1 HNO3 solution for 24 h and then washed with deionized water to neutral pH, for the next cycle adsorption.

elements.content: MOF 1 crystallizes in monoclinic space group C2/c with the asymmetric unit comprising one [Cd­(ADB)­L2] unit. As illustrated in a, each Cd1 atom is coordinated with four O atoms from two chelating carboxylate groups of ADB2– ligand and three N atoms of L ligands to furnish the distorted pentagonal bipyramidal coordination geometry. Each Cd atom is interlinked by bridging ADB2– ligands to afford a one-dimensional (1D)­[Cd­(ADB)] n chain (Figure S3). Each chain is linked to adjacent chains by L ligands to generate a two-dimensional (2D) (4,4) layer. Furthermore, other L ligands were employed as pillars to link the 2D layers to produce a three-dimensional (3D) framework with 1D pores (b), which was calculated by the Platon program to have an effective solvent accessible volume of 2675.2 Å3 for every unit cell (24.2% of the overall cell volume). The size of the pores of framework is 3.871 Å × 8.175 Å (Figure S4). However, based on the N2 adsorption–desorption measurement, we could not get expected results to calculate the pore distribution and surface area (Figure S5). This phenomenon can be ascribed to the loss of the long-range order under high vacuum for the frameworks and generally happens to some highly porous MOFs. Interestingly, abundant carbomethoxy, methoxy, and diazene groups were located on the pore wall (b), which may favor Pb­(II) adsorption.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Characterization of 1 

MOF 1 crystallizes in monoclinic space group C2/c with the asymmetric unit comprising one [Cd(ADB)L2] unit. As illustrated in a, each Cd1 atom is coordinated with four O atoms from two chelating carboxylate groups of ADB2- ligand and three N atoms of L ligands to furnish the distorted pentagonal bipyramidal coordination geometry. Each Cd atom is interlinked by bridging ADB2- ligands to afford a one-dimensional (1D)[Cd(ADB)] n  chain (Figure S3). Each chain is linked to adjacent chains by L ligands to generate a two-dimensional (2D) (4,4) layer. Furthermore, other L ligands were employed as pillars to link the 2D layers to produce a three-dimensional (3D) framework with 1D pores (b), which was calculated by the Platon program to have an effective solvent accessible volume of 2675.2 Å3 for every unit cell (24.2% of the overall cell volume). The size of the pores of framework is 3.871 Å × 8.175 Å (Figure S4). However, based on the N2 adsorption-desorption measurement, we could not get expected results to calculate the pore distribution and surface area (Figure S5). This phenomenon can be ascribed to the loss of the long-range order under high vacuum for the frameworks and generally happens to some highly porous MOFs. Interestingly, abundant carbomethoxy, methoxy, and diazene groups were located on the pore wall (b), which may favor Pb(II) adsorption.

elements.content: The pH is a key factor governing the uptake of the adsorbate on adsorbent since it affects the speciation of the adsorbate and the state of chemically active sites on adsorbent. The adsorption process was investigated over an initial pH ranging from 3.0 to 7.0. To avoid precipitation, pH higher than 7.0 was not investigated. As depicted in and S6, with pH increasing, the adsorption capacity increased, while the zeta potential of MOF 1 decreased with an isoelectric point at pH of 3.4. Thus, the effect of pH on Pb­(II) uptake capacity could be stemmed from the electrostatic interaction between MOF 1 and Pb­(II). At pH lower than 3.0, the adsorption capacities were not obvious, which was mainly ascribed to the partial dissolution and protonation of the MOF, affording the diminishing sorption sites and electrostatic repulsion between MOF 1 and Pb­(II). With pH increasing, the zeta potential of 1 appeared to be more negative, and the resulted stronger electrostatic attraction between MOF 1 and Pb­(II) afforded higher uptake capacity. The maximum uptake capacity was reached at pH of 7.0. When pH was higher than 7.0, Pb­(II) started to precipitate, leading the interactions between the O atoms and Pb­(II) to be weakened. As a result, pH of 7.0 was selected as the optimum pH for the following adsorption experiments.
elements.clean_text:
Pb(II) Sorption Studies

The pH is a key factor governing the uptake of the adsorbate on adsorbent since it affects the speciation of the adsorbate and the state of chemically active sites on adsorbent. The adsorption process was investigated over an initial pH ranging from 3.0 to 7.0. To avoid precipitation, pH higher than 7.0 was not investigated. As depicted in  and S6, with pH increasing, the adsorption capacity increased, while the zeta potential of MOF 1 decreased with an isoelectric point at pH of 3.4. Thus, the effect of pH on Pb(II) uptake capacity could be stemmed from the electrostatic interaction between MOF 1 and Pb(II). At pH lower than 3.0, the adsorption capacities were not obvious, which was mainly ascribed to the partial dissolution and protonation of the MOF, affording the diminishing sorption sites and electrostatic repulsion between MOF 1 and Pb(II). With pH increasing, the zeta potential of 1 appeared to be more negative, and the resulted stronger electrostatic attraction between MOF 1 and Pb(II) afforded higher uptake capacity. The maximum uptake capacity was reached at pH of 7.0. When pH was higher than 7.0, Pb(II) started to precipitate, leading the interactions between the O atoms and Pb(II) to be weakened. As a result, pH of 7.0 was selected as the optimum pH for the following adsorption experiments.

elements.content: Kinetic parameters can be used to define the adsorption efficiency, and fast kinetics is of great significance and useful in aqueous phase adsorption. To evaluate the kinetic parameters of MOF 1, the effect of contact time on Pb­(II) adsorption was explored. As illustrated in , fairly fast kinetics were achieved and 99.3% of final adsorption capacity was reached in 5 min. Compared with various reported Pb­(II) adsorbents under similar conditions (Table S1), MOF 1 showed an ultrafast adsorption rate. To further study the mechanism of the adsorption kinetics, the collected experimental data were fitted with the pseudo-first-order kinetic model, pseudo-second-order kinetic model, and the intraparticle diffusion model.

To further study the mechanism of the adsorption kinetics, the collected experimental data were fitted with the pseudo-first-order kinetic model, pseudo-second-order kinetic model, and the intraparticle diffusion model.

elements.content: The fitting results of the experimental data are shown in , and the calculated parameters are presented in Table S2. As the plot does not pass through the origin, the intraparticle diffusion is not the only rate limiting step of adsorption (c). By comparison of the correlation coefficients, the pseudo-second-order model (R 2 = 0.999) fits the data better, and the calculated q e value is in good agreement with the experimental value (b), suggesting the pseudo second-order mechanism is predominant and chemisorption is the rate limiting step of adsorption. The derived kinetic rate constant k 2 was calculated to be 0.162 g mg–1 min–1, which is significantly higher than other Pb­(II) adsorbents (Table S1) and outperforming various benchmark materials, for example, modified activated carbon (1.22 × 10–3 g mg–1 min–1), Magnetic Fly Ash/Poly­(acrylic acid) composite microgels (1.53 × 10–6 g mg–1 min–1), chitosan/silica nanofibers (6.99 × 10–4 g mg–1 min–1), l-glutamic acid-functionalized graphene oxide (1.684 × 10–4 g mg–1 min–1), Fe3O4 nanoparticles (1.2 × 10–3 g mg–1 min–1), and CoS2-carbon dot nanohybrid composites (2.3 × 10–3 g mg–1 min–1). From the structural viewpoint, the carbomethoxy groups in the pores of MOF 1 hold the potential to coordinate with Pb­(II), thereby acting as active sites for Pb­(II) sorption.

elements.content: To estimate the maximum uptake capacity for Pb­(II), the adsorption isotherms were investigated at pH 7.0 with concentrations ranging from 0.1 to 20 ppm. As shown in , the equilibrium adsorption capacity increased along with the increase of Pb­(II) initial concentration and reached a plateau of ca. 60.857 mg g–1. Langmuir model and Freundlich model were employed to simulate the isotherm data. The plots were graphed in , and the corresponding parameters were listed in Table S3. Comparing the linear regression coefficient (R 2) values for the two models, the Langmuir model (R 2 = 0.994) is more suitable for describing the adsorption process, indicating a mainly monolayer adsorption behavior on MOF 1. The calculated maximum adsorption capacity q m is 63.052 mg g–1, approaching the experimental data of 60.857 mg g–1. The derived Langmuir constant K L was measured to be 3.622 L mg–1, which was 1–3 orders of magnitude higher than other Pb­(II) adsorbent materials.

elements.content: The adsorption capacity for Pb­(II) is not so high, mainly ascribed to the smaller aperture of MOF 1. However, owing to the existence of extensive free-standing carbomethoxy groups in the pores, a fast adsorption equilibrium with a high removal efficiency was obtained, even in a relatively low concentration of Pb­(II) solution. After treatment with 7 mg of MOF adsorbents, a concentration of Pb­(II) at 0.1 ppm (100 mL) can be reduced to 0.004 ppm within 10 min, which indicated that the concentration of the residue Pb­(II) is not only lower than the Environmental Protection Agency standard (0.05 ppm) for drinking water but also below the acceptable limit by drinking water standard of the World Health Organization (0.01 ppm). The good adsorption performance for fast kinetics and high removal efficiency may stem from the strong affinity of MOF 1 toward Pb­(II).

elements.content: The distribution coefficient (K d) was employed to evaluate the affinity, and it was calculated by the following equation: K d = ( C 0 − C e ) C e × V m where C 0 (mg L–1) and C e (mg L–1) are the initial and equilibrium Pb­(II) concentration, respectively. V (mL) is the volume of the solution, and m (g) is the weight of the adsorbent. Generally, a material with a K d value above 104 mL g–1 is regarded as an outstanding adsorbent. The K d of 1 for Pb­(II) was calculated to be 6.81 × 105 mL g–1. Compared with other adsorbents, MOF 1 exhibited a significant affinity and exceeded many Pb­(II) adsorbents under similar condition, for example, nanozirconium silicate-functionalized-3-aminopropyltrimethoxysilane (1.047 × 104 mL g–1), MoS4-LDH (2.6 × 105 mL g–1), polyaniline-tin­(IV) molybdophosphate (8 × 102 – 8 × 103 mL g–1), Pampeano aquifer (7.5 × 103 – 1 × 104 mL g–1), nanozirconium silicate (6.24 × 103 mL g–1), and biochars (103 – 104 mL g–1).

elements.content: The metal ions in the environment were often found to be in a matrix containing various ions. If other metal ions could be well adsorbed by MOF 1, the uptake capacity for Pb­(II) would greatly decrease. So, it is imperative to investigate the selective adsorption in the existence of different metal ions. The selectivity tests were conducted in a mixed solution including Pb­(II), Na­(I), Mg­(II), K­(I), Ca­(II), Zn­(II), Co­(II), Ni­(II), and Cd­(II) ions. As shown in Figure S7 and Table S4, MOF 1 can effectively adsorb Pb­(II), together with other heavy metal ions of Zn­(II), Co­(II), Ni­(II), and Cd­(II), while Na­(I), Mg­(II), K­(I), and Ca­(II) do not quite bind to 1. As the carbomethoxy group in MOF 1 is a soft base, it could readily bind with borderline acids of Pb­(II), Zn­(II), Co­(II), Ni­(II), and Cd­(II), based on the HSAB principle. Lower removal efficiencies were obtained for the borderline acids of Zn­(II), Co­(II), Ni­(II), and Cd­(II) by comparison with Pb­(II). It may stem from their fairly high hydration energy (1955 kJ mol–1 for Zn­(II), 1915 kJ mol–1 for Co­(II), 1980 kJ mol–1 for Ni­(II), 1755 kJ mol–1 for Cd­(II), and 1425 kJ mol–1 for Pb­(II)). Furthermore, larger ionic radius would be favorable for the interactions with the functional groups of adsorbents, and Pb­(II) possess a larger radius (0.119 nm) compared to that of Zn­(II) (0.075 nm), Co­(II) (0.075 nm), Ni­(II) (0.069 nm), and Cd­(II) (0.095 nm). These results revealed that MOF 1 could selectively capture Pb­(II) in aqueous solution.

elements.content: Thermodynamic studies were investigated at 298–318 K to estimate the feasibility and exothermic nature in the adsorption process. The calculated thermodynamic parameters of ΔG° (standard free energy), ΔH° (enthalpy change), and ΔS° (entropy change) were provided in Table S5. The negative ΔG° values at different temperatures indicated the feasibility and spontaneity of Pb­(II) adsorption by MOF 1. Positive ΔH° suggested that the adsorption was endothermic and that it is unfavorable for spontaneous adsorption, while the positive ΔS° was beneficial for spontaneous adsorption, which may be ascribed to the departure of more water molecules from Pb­(II) hydrate before a Pb­(II) ion or partially dehydrated Pb­(II) hydrate was adsorbed. Therefore, the driving force in Pb­(II) adsorption on MOF 1 was controlled by an entropy effect rather than an enthalpy change.

elements.content: To demonstrate the stability of MOF 1, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) investigations were employed to determine the crystalline structure. After soaking MOF 1 in aqueous solution at pH of 4.0 for 24 h, it still holds the crystalline form, indicating its good chemical stability (Figure S8). The chemical stability of Pb­(II)-loaded MOF 1 was further confirmed by the good match of PXRD patterns with MOF 1 samples (Figure S9). Meanwhile, energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM) measurements were performed to examine the chemical composition and surface morphology of MOF 1 after Pb­(II) adsorption. As shown in Figure S10, the crystals did not collapse during the loading process in the temperature range from 298 to 318 K. The EDS spectra also confirmed the existence of Pb­(II) (Figure S11). To further verify that Pb­(II) was loaded, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was also studied (). By comparison, MOF 1 samples showed a weight loss of 9.8% at 40–180 °C, corresponding to solvent molecule, while the Pb­(II)-loaded samples displayed smaller weight loss (3.2%) of solvent molecule. After heated to ca. 900 °C, the remaining weight of MOF 1 samples and Pb­(II)-loaded samples were 28.9% and 34.8%, respectively. These results directly supported the fact that Pb­(II) was loaded.
elements.clean_text:
Stability and Reusability Study of the Adsorbent

To demonstrate the stability of MOF 1, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) investigations were employed to determine the crystalline structure. After soaking MOF 1 in aqueous solution at pH of 4.0 for 24 h, it still holds the crystalline form, indicating its good chemical stability (Figure S8). The chemical stability of Pb(II)-loaded MOF 1 was further confirmed by the good match of PXRD patterns with MOF 1 samples (Figure S9). Meanwhile, energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM) measurements were performed to examine the chemical composition and surface morphology of MOF 1 after Pb(II) adsorption. As shown in Figure S10, the crystals did not collapse during the loading process in the temperature range from 298 to 318 K. The EDS spectra also confirmed the existence of Pb(II) (Figure S11). To further verify that Pb(II) was loaded, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was also studied (). By comparison, MOF 1 samples showed a weight loss of 9.8% at 40-180 °C, corresponding to solvent molecule, while the Pb(II)-loaded samples displayed smaller weight loss (3.2%) of solvent molecule. After heated to ca. 900 °C, the remaining weight of MOF 1 samples and Pb(II)-loaded samples were 28.9% and 34.8%, respectively. These results directly supported the fact that Pb(II) was loaded.

elements.content: The cycles of adsorption/desorption were carried out to evaluate the reusability of MOF 1. As shown in Figure S12, MOF 1 exhibited an acceptable cycle performance. The uptake capacity slightly decreased with the recycled process, which may be ascribed to chemical adsorption or the loss of the adsorbent during cycling. Similar results were also reported in previous studies.

elements.content: According to the aforementioned research, we came to a conclusion that MOF 1 could efficiently remove Pb­(II) with high efficiency and fast kinetics, even in a low concentration, which can be ascribed to the strong affinity of the sorbent toward Pb­(II). To gain further insight into the good performance for Pb­(II) removal, Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed to evaluate the interaction between Pb­(II) and MOF 1. In , after treatment with Pb­(II), a new peak appearing at 696 cm–1 was the stretching vibration of Pb–O, confirming that Pb­(II) was loaded. According to the literature, Pb­(II) was adsorbed mainly in the form of partially dehydrated Pb­(II) hydrates. The bands at 798 and 1378 cm–1 occurred after Pb­(II) adsorption, implying the presence of NO3 –, for charge balance. Moreover, an obvious red shift from 1713 to 1706 cm–1 was observed for the characteristic CO stretching vibration after Pb­(II) adsorption, which is possibly due to the coordination between Pb­(II) and the O atom of CO unit. On the contrary, the stretching vibration of the C–O unit in carbomethoxy groups demonstrates a blue shift from 1249 to 1257 cm–1. This further confirmed that Pb­(II) has a coordination with the CO unit, and it weakens the interaction between the CO unit and C–O bond in the carbomethoxy groups, thereby making the C–O bond more free and their vibration stronger.
elements.clean_text:
Mechanism for Removal of Pb(II)

According to the aforementioned research, we came to a conclusion that MOF 1 could efficiently remove Pb(II) with high efficiency and fast kinetics, even in a low concentration, which can be ascribed to the strong affinity of the sorbent toward Pb(II). To gain further insight into the good performance for Pb(II) removal, Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed to evaluate the interaction between Pb(II) and MOF 1. In , after treatment with Pb(II), a new peak appearing at 696 cm-1 was the stretching vibration of Pb-O, confirming that Pb(II) was loaded. According to the literature, Pb(II) was adsorbed mainly in the form of partially dehydrated Pb(II) hydrates. The bands at 798 and 1378 cm-1 occurred after Pb(II) adsorption, implying the presence of NO3 -, for charge balance. Moreover, an obvious red shift from 1713 to 1706 cm-1 was observed for the characteristic CO stretching vibration after Pb(II) adsorption, which is possibly due to the coordination between Pb(II) and the O atom of CO unit. On the contrary, the stretching vibration of the C-O unit in carbomethoxy groups demonstrates a blue shift from 1249 to 1257 cm-1. This further confirmed that Pb(II) has a coordination with the CO unit, and it weakens the interaction between the CO unit and C-O bond in the carbomethoxy groups, thereby making the C-O bond more free and their vibration stronger.

elements.content: XPS measurements were also conducted to provide more information on the interaction between Pb­(II) and MOF 1. As shown in a, the appearance of Pb 4f, Pb 4d, and Pb 4p peaks verified that Pb­(II) was undoubtedly loaded on 1. A detailed comparison between samples of Pb­(II)-loaded 1 and Pb­(NO3)2 was presented in the high-resolution XPS spectrum of Pb 4f (b). For Pb­(II)-loaded 1, two peaks located at 143.1 and 138.2 eV were attributed to Pb 4f5/2 and Pb 4f7/2. Compared with Pb­(II) binding energies of purified Pb­(NO3)2, which centered at 144.5 eV for 4f5/2 and 139.6 eV for Pb 4f7/2, a remarkable shift of 1.4 eV to a lower binding energy was observed for the Pb­(II)-loaded sample, revealing the strong affinities between MOF 1 and Pb­(II). An energy separation of 4.9 eV was observed for the peaks of Pb 4f5/2 (143.1 eV) and Pb 4f7/2 (138.2 eV) in Pb­(II)-loaded 1. It can be attributed to PbO, suggesting that Pb­(II) was bonded with the O atoms in the pores of the adsorbent, which was consistent with the FT-IR analyses.

elements.content: Based on the above results, we speculated that the carbomethoxy groups played a vital role in capturing Pb­(II), while other free-standing groups, methoxy and diazene, were not involved in the process of Pb­(II) adsorption. As shown in , the O atoms (O6 and O9) of carbomethoxy groups located in the pores of MOF 1 give facile access to coordinate with Pb­(II). Moreover, the CO bond extended straight to the center of the pore, leaving almost no steric hindrance to interact with Pb­(II), while the O atoms (O7 and O10) of methoxy groups were surrounded by methylene and phenyl groups, making it inconvenient to approach Pb­(II). For the diazene groups, Pb­(II) prefers complexing with the O atoms from the carbomethoxy groups to N atoms of the diazene groups, as the oxygen is more electronegative than the nitrogen. What’s more, the positions that diazene groups located did not favor Pb­(II) sorption, which renders the interaction between diazene groups and Pb­(II) more difficult.

Moreover, the CO bond extended straight to the center of the pore, leaving almost no steric hindrance to interact with Pb(II), while the O atoms (O7 and O10) of methoxy groups were surrounded by methylene and phenyl groups, making it inconvenient to approach Pb(II). For the diazene groups, Pb(II) prefers complexing with the O atoms from the carbomethoxy groups to N atoms of the diazene groups, as the oxygen is more electronegative than the nitrogen. What's more, the positions that diazene groups located did not favor Pb(II) sorption, which renders the interaction between diazene groups and Pb(II) more difficult.

elements.content: In conclusion, a novel MOF decorated with carbomethoxy groups was designed and synthesized for the removal of Pb­(II). Notably, without any sample pretreatment, this MOF material exhibited fast kinetics and high removal efficiency. Even in the low concentration system, effective removal can also be achieved. The characterization of MOF adsorbents before and after Pb­(II) adsorption suggested that the good adsorption performance mainly originates from the interaction of Pb/OC–O, which gives rise to a significant affinity between Pb­(II) and MOF 1. This offers a new way to construct MOFs decorated with free-standing groups for efficient removal of other heavy metal ions.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion, a novel MOF decorated with carbomethoxy groups was designed and synthesized for the removal of Pb(II). Notably, without any sample pretreatment, this MOF material exhibited fast kinetics and high removal efficiency. Even in the low concentration system, effective removal can also be achieved. The characterization of MOF adsorbents before and after Pb(II) adsorption suggested that the good adsorption performance mainly originates from the interaction of Pb/OC-O, which gives rise to a significant affinity between Pb(II) and MOF 1. This offers a new way to construct MOFs decorated with free-standing groups for efficient removal of other heavy metal ions.

cln_elements.content:
Lead (Pb) is one of the most widespread toxic heavy metals, and how to quickly and completely remove trace Pb­(II) is a global concern. Herein, we prepared a novel metal–organic framework (MOF) {[Cd­(ADB)­L2]·1.5DMF·2H2O} n (1) decorated with carbomethoxy groups and investigated the Pb­(II) removal performance as well as the underlying mechanism. The MOF exhibits a fast kinetics with the kinetic rate constant k 2 of 0.162 g mg–1 min–1, which is 1–3 orders of magnitude higher than the reported Pb­(II) adsorbent materials. In addition, even in a concentration of 0.1 ppm, a high removal efficiency (96%) was still obtained after the treatment with the metal–organic framework, and the concentration was reduced to 0.004 ppm, which is well below the drinking water standard of the World Health Organization (0.01 ppm). The possible adsorption mechanism was systematically verified by Fourier-transform infrared and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy investigations. The significant affinity between carbomethoxy groups and Pb­(II) is responsible for the good removal performance.

Results and DiscussionCharacterization of <bold>1</bold>

MOF 1 crystallizes in monoclinic space group C2/c with the asymmetric unit comprising one [Cd­(ADB)­L2] unit. As illustrated in a, each Cd1 atom is coordinated with four O atoms from two chelating carboxylate groups of ADB2– ligand and three N atoms of L ligands to furnish the distorted pentagonal bipyramidal coordination geometry. Each Cd atom is interlinked by bridging ADB2– ligands to afford a one-dimensional (1D)­[Cd­(ADB)] n chain (Figure S3). Each chain is linked to adjacent chains by L ligands to generate a two-dimensional (2D) (4,4) layer. Furthermore, other L ligands were employed as pillars to link the 2D layers to produce a three-dimensional (3D) framework with 1D pores (b), which was calculated by the Platon program to have an effective solvent accessible volume of 2675.2 Å3 for every unit cell (24.2% of the overall cell volume). The size of the pores of framework is 3.871 Å × 8.175 Å (Figure S4). However, based on the N2 adsorption–desorption measurement, we could not get expected results to calculate the pore distribution and surface area (Figure S5). This phenomenon can be ascribed to the loss of the long-range order under high vacuum for the frameworks and generally happens to some highly porous MOFs. Interestingly, abundant carbomethoxy, methoxy, and diazene groups were located on the pore wall (b), which may favor Pb­(II) adsorption.

To estimate the maximum uptake capacity for Pb­(II), the adsorption isotherms were investigated at pH 7.0 with concentrations ranging from 0.1 to 20 ppm. As shown in , the equilibrium adsorption capacity increased along with the increase of Pb­(II) initial concentration and reached a plateau of ca. 60.857 mg g–1. Langmuir model and Freundlich model were employed to simulate the isotherm data. The plots were graphed in , and the corresponding parameters were listed in Table S3. Comparing the linear regression coefficient (R 2) values for the two models, the Langmuir model (R 2 = 0.994) is more suitable for describing the adsorption process, indicating a mainly monolayer adsorption behavior on MOF 1. The calculated maximum adsorption capacity q m is 63.052 mg g–1, approaching the experimental data of 60.857 mg g–1. The derived Langmuir constant K L was measured to be 3.622 L mg–1, which was 1–3 orders of magnitude higher than other Pb­(II) adsorbent materials.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Lead (Pb) is one of the most widespread toxic heavy metals, and how to quickly and completely remove trace Pb(II) is a global concern. Herein, we prepared a novel metal-organic framework (MOF) {[Cd(ADB)L2]⋅1.5DMF⋅2H2O} n  (1) decorated with carbomethoxy groups and investigated the Pb(II) removal performance as well as the underlying mechanism. The MOF exhibits a fast kinetics with the kinetic rate constant k 2 of 0.162 g mg-1 min-1, which is 1-3 orders of magnitude higher than the reported Pb(II) adsorbent materials. In addition, even in a concentration of 0.1 ppm, a high removal efficiency (96%) was still obtained after the treatment with the metal-organic framework, and the concentration was reduced to 0.004 ppm, which is well below the drinking water standard of the World Health Organization (0.01 ppm). The possible adsorption mechanism was systematically verified by Fourier-transform infrared and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy investigations. The significant affinity between carbomethoxy groups and Pb(II) is responsible for the good removal performance.

Results and Discussion

Characterization of 1 

MOF 1 crystallizes in monoclinic space group C2/c with the asymmetric unit comprising one [Cd(ADB)L2] unit. As illustrated in a, each Cd1 atom is coordinated with four O atoms from two chelating carboxylate groups of ADB2- ligand and three N atoms of L ligands to furnish the distorted pentagonal bipyramidal coordination geometry. Each Cd atom is interlinked by bridging ADB2- ligands to afford a one-dimensional (1D)[Cd(ADB)] n  chain (Figure S3). Each chain is linked to adjacent chains by L ligands to generate a two-dimensional (2D) (4,4) layer. Furthermore, other L ligands were employed as pillars to link the 2D layers to produce a three-dimensional (3D) framework with 1D pores (b), which was calculated by the Platon program to have an effective solvent accessible volume of 2675.2 Å3 for every unit cell (24.2% of the overall cell volume). The size of the pores of framework is 3.871 Å × 8.175 Å (Figure S4). However, based on the N2 adsorption-desorption measurement, we could not get expected results to calculate the pore distribution and surface area (Figure S5). This phenomenon can be ascribed to the loss of the long-range order under high vacuum for the frameworks and generally happens to some highly porous MOFs. Interestingly, abundant carbomethoxy, methoxy, and diazene groups were located on the pore wall (b), which may favor Pb(II) adsorption.

To estimate the maximum uptake capacity for Pb(II), the adsorption isotherms were investigated at pH 7.0 with concentrations ranging from 0.1 to 20 ppm. As shown in , the equilibrium adsorption capacity increased along with the increase of Pb(II) initial concentration and reached a plateau of ca. 60.857 mg g-1. Langmuir model and Freundlich model were employed to simulate the isotherm data. The plots were graphed in , and the corresponding parameters were listed in Table S3. Comparing the linear regression coefficient (R 2) values for the two models, the Langmuir model (R 2 = 0.994) is more suitable for describing the adsorption process, indicating a mainly monolayer adsorption behavior on MOF 1. The calculated maximum adsorption capacity q m is 63.052 mg g-1, approaching the experimental data of 60.857 mg g-1. The derived Langmuir constant K L was measured to be 3.622 L mg-1, which was 1-3 orders of magnitude higher than other Pb(II) adsorbent materials.
